results.title: Poland: the will to be
results.creator_credit: Emlen House Productions and Albert Waller
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Michener’s World”.
Documentary film, narrated by James Michener, which looks at the history of Poland since its “first birth”. Shows the gaining of independence after Versailles, the invasion by Germany in 1939 and the Russian intervention during the war. Finally concentrates on the social-political structure of modern Poland. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Poland: the land and the people
results.brief_description: A geographical and historical view of Poland and her people in 1961. Poland’s place in the world as a nation under communism. Life on a small farmily farm and in mining and industrial regions; Poland’s efforts at industrial diversification; the role of Poland in international trade.

results.title: Poland: a proud heritage
results.creator_credit: Hughes Leisure Group, Chris Valentini and Andrew K Slodkowski
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Visit Poland, the land of lakes, palaces, forests, cathedrals, sandy beaches and heroes and legends of the past. Visit the capital of Warsaw with its newly restored historical buildings. In Castle Square see the Royal Castle and Sigmund’s Column, the symbol of the city. Travel to Cracow’s Wawel Hill, the ancient seat of Polish kings and hear Polish folklore in the Tatras mountains. Experience the serenity of Bialowieza, Europe’s last virgin woodland. Pause in reflection at the Auschwitz Memorial, travel down the Dunajec River and visit the monastery of Jasna Gora, to see the Black Madonna.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hughes Leisure Group, Chris Valentini and Andrew K Slodkowski

results.title: Poland and the Soviet power
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, John Barnes and Kenneth Richter
results.brief_description: Poland’s recent history and relations with Soviet Union and the ‘West’ since 1939; Polish underground; Nazi occupation; Russian liberation; events of October 1956; Gomulka’s defiance of Russia and insistence that Poland’s Independence must be respected; gains of religious freedom, private business and privately owned farms; excessive taxation and restrictions of the press.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, John Barnes and Kenneth Richter

results.title: Poland
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation, Walter J. Carroll and Julien Bryan
results.brief_description: An introduction (using animation) showing growth and decline of power before World War II, destruction during the war and reconstruction after. Shows rural life being replaced by urbanization; Poland’s past struggle for independence; fluctuations in government; and previous influence and an analysis of the present industrialization, agriculture, politics and position in the world.

results.title: Poland
results.brief_description: Shows Warsaw and historic buildings. Warsaw has half of the total world population of Jews. Zinc is its prime export. In the country large estates, presided over by peasants are shown. School life includes lace making and woodcraft. In the main port of Gdynia, coal and lumber and the main exports.

results.title: Pola x [Widescreen] (E)
results.creator_credit: Arena Films, Polar Productions, Bruno Pesery and Leos Carax
results.brief_description: Leos Carax’s first feature since 1991’s “Les Amants du Pont Neuf” uses as its source material Herman Melville’s novel “Pierre or, the ambiguities”. In this modernisation of the novel, the comfortable world of privileged and idealistic novelist Pierre (Guillaume Depardieu) falls apart when he discovers that he has a sister called Isabelle, whose existence was kept secret from him by his possessive mother (Catherine Deneuve). This shock revelation causes Pierre to leave behind his charmed life and head to Paris where he embarks on a new novel and a journey to uncover the truth of the world. He soon discovers the dark side of human nature as he begins to slide into despair and embarks on a destructive relationship with his troubled sister. “Pola x” stumbles at times as it slips between youthful romanticism and utter nihilism. However it’s too easy to criticise Carax’s ambitious project or merely dismiss it as pretentious as some critics had. Ultimately “Pola x” maps a complex terrain, a grand, sweeping diatribe on contemporary society and, with that, it’s hard not to feel that Carax is as romantic and idealised as his tragic hero. Cast includes: Katerina Golubeva, Delphine Chuillot. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Poky little puppy
results.creator_credit: Little Golden Books Films, Sandler Institutional Films, Zagreb Film and Allan Frank Sandler
results.brief_description: An animated cartoon about five puppies, one of whom calculates how to eat the desserts of the others. Designed to teach reading and number recognition. For primary grades. Based on the book of the same title by Janette Sebring Lowrey. Consultant Chuck Jones-Animator

results.title: Pokemon: The Mystery of Mount Moon
results.creator_credit: Nintendo, Norman J Grossfeld, Michael Haigney and Jim Malone
results.brief_description: Pokemon trainer Ash Ketchum continues his quest to become the world’s greatest Pokemon master. He’s already caught two of the amazing creatures with the help of Pikachu. Together with Misty, they’ll travel across the land searching far and wide for all 150 Pokemon - he’s gotta catch ‘em all to be the very best. There are plenty of new creatures to learn about (and friends to meet) in this second set of Pokemon adventures. In Japanese, dubbed into English.

results.title: Pokemon: I choose you! Pikachu!
results.creator_credit: Shogakukan Production Co Ltd, 4 Kids Productions, Keisuke Iwata, Takayuki Yanagisawa, Takamoto Mori and Masamitsu Hidaka
results.brief_description: This volume contains the first three episodes of the Japanese (English Dubbed) cartoon. The first episode, entitled “I Choose You! Pikachu!” sees Ash, a ten year old boy get his first Pokemon (pocket monster). Having been late to the ceremony for choosing Pokemon, Ash is left with the last Pokemon, an electric rat Pokemon called Pikachu. After a bumpy start the two learn to work as a team to fight off a flock of Spearows: aggressive flying Pokemon. The second episode, entitled “Pokemon Emergency!” continues from the end of the battle with the Spearows in which Pikachu is badly hurt. Ash then has to rush his Pokemon to the special Pokemon hospital. While Ash waits for Pikachu to recover, the hospital is attacked by Team Rocket, an evil team of Pokemon thieves. Pikachu recovers just in time to work with Ash to scare off Team Rocket. Ash then continues on his quest to become a Pokemon master followed by Misty, a young girl who helped him save Pikachu. In third episode, entitled “Ash Catches a Pokemon”, Ash manages to catch his very first Pokemon, a big Pokemon called Caterpie. While Misty does not like Caterpie to begin with, things start to change after Caterpie saves the day when Team Rocket attempts another attack on Ash, Pikachu and Misty. Pokemon the series is based the Nintendo game of the same name.
